urn:contentItem:6GPM-DY53-RRY1-F24K-00000-00Pictou tackling climate change through federal green fund2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T06:21:43ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSPictou tackling climate change through federal green fundTom Peters, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterThe Advocate

The Town of Pictou, like many other Nova Scotia municipalities, is moving forward with plans to tackle the complex issues of climate change.

The town is one of 11 Nova Scotia municipalities to receive funding through the federal Green Municipal Fund’s (GMF) Local Leadership for Climate Adaptation (LLCA) initiative. The funding is earmarked to support projects that will strengthen climate resilience through climate adaptation plans, climate-focused asset management strategies and community-wide climate risk assessments.

The town recently received $70,000 from the fund

Chief administrative officer (CAO) Kyle Slaunwhite says the money “is going to be for a joint opportunity between the town and the county. We are hiring a climate change specialist to help us advance a few climate change initiatives. So specifically for the Town of Pictou, we are going to update our 2013 municipal climate adaptation plans.” 

Slaunwhite said the town is going to identify some natural asset inventory, like park green space, park space, trail networks, waterways, etc and ‘hopefully, after we identify, put them toward a plan on how to enhance them.”

Furthermore, he said, the town plans to use the funding to hire a new full-time environmentalist and use this person’s review of all current climate change rifts within the community and make recommendations on how to address them.”

With a full-time environmentalist “on board” it is a “great opportunity for us for the next two years to really work within our community and with our partners at the county, to find ways to make sure we are ready for the future and what climate impacts are going to be,” Slaunwhite said.

The Pictou spokesman said the $70,000 will be spread over two years with additional funding from the town and county. Both will be required to contribute funds annually to top up to a reasonable cost of living for that position.

The CAO said the interview process for the environmentalist has actually been completed and “we are hopeful that within the next month, announce who that person is and have them attend future council meetings.

“With a lot going on it is terrifying to look even within our own province with the disasters that are happening. Even right now we really hope we are able to get ahead of these (climate events) the best we can and at least this will give us a step in the right direction,” Slaunwhite added.

A further example of where the municipalities are headed with climate programs is Cape Breton’s Victoria County which also received $70,000.

“The funding will support both the plan and a training component. Together, these will help municipal staff become better equipped to adapt to and respond to climate change,” said municipal spokesperson, Ursula Melski. At this time, there is no timeline when the plan will be complete.

The long drought being experienced in Nova Scotia this year, is an example of the environmental impacts climate change can have on Atlantic Canada.

However, Pictou is not dealing with a water shortage.

Slaunwhite said the town is not having any issues with its water currently because “we have secure groundwater which is not impacted by heat waves as much as some of the surface water supplies. We are keeping a close eye and asking the people to be smart with their water.” He said if a major fire or some other climate event happened the situation could quickly change.

Other northeastern Nova Scotia municipalities receiving funding through the Green Municipal Fund’s (GMF) Local Leadership for Climate Adaptation (LLCA) initiative include the County of Antigonish, $70,000; Cape Breton Regional Municipality, $104,550; Municipality of the County of Inverness $70,000; and the Municipality of the County of Richmond, $70,000.
